title: Feuerbach's Theorem
description: The nine-point circle of a triangle is tangent to its incircle and all three excircles. A beautiful result in triangle geometry.

meta.author: Karl Wilhelm Feuerbach (1822)
originalContributions: Framework for triangles, nine-point circle, incircle, excircles

overview.historicalContext: Feuerbach proved this theorem in 1822 at age 22. The nine-point circle passes through 9 special points of a triangle (midpoints of sides, feet of altitudes, midpoints of segments from vertices to orthocenter). Feuerbach showed this circle has a remarkable tangency property.
overview.problemStatement:
**Feuerbach's Theorem**: The nine-point circle of any triangle is tangent to the incircle and to each of the three excircles.

The point of tangency with the incircle is called the Feuerbach point.
overview.proofStrategy: Modern proofs often use inversion or complex numbers. The key is to show that the distance between the centers of the nine-point circle and incircle equals the difference of their radii (internal tangency).
keyInsights: The nine-point circle has radius exactly half the circumradius
Internal tangency with incircle, external tangency with excircles
The Feuerbach point lies on the nine-point circle
Generalizes to remarkable properties of triangle centers

conclusion.summary: Feuerbach's theorem is one of the most beautiful results in triangle geometry, revealing a hidden connection between the nine-point circle and the incircle/excircles that was unknown for millennia.
conclusion.implications: The theorem inspired much research in triangle geometry and the study of triangle centers, leading to the Encyclopedia of Triangle Centers with thousands of special points.
openQuestions: What is the 3D analogue for tetrahedra?
How does Feuerbach's theorem generalize to other geometries?
What are all the tangent circles in a triangle?
